#Text=Iraqi Kurdistan
#Text=Kurdistan ( Kurdish : کوردستان ) refers to portions of Turkey , Iraq , Iran and Syria , however only the Iraqi region of Kurdistan is discussed here .
#Text=See the articles on Turkey , Western Iran and Syria for information regarding the other regions of Kurdistan .
#Text=Understand
#Text=Having been spared the war of 2003 , Kurdistan-Iraq is a very different place from middle and southern Iraq .

#Text=With a minimal level of terrorist activity and massive economic development , Kurdistan is fast becoming a " gateway to Iraq " with high levels of foreign investment and development of infrastructure and tourism .
#Text=Be careful when discussing nationalist issues which many Kurds feel strongly about .

#Text=Also read up on the Al-Anfal campaign and chemical attack on the Kurds by Saddam Hussein to exterminate droves of Kurds in the late 1980s , an event which has colored the last few decades of Kurdish history .
#Text=There are several powerful reminders of it , such as the Amna Suraka prison in Sulaymaniya .

#Text=And be careful about calling a Kurd Iraqi because they do n't count themselves as Iraqi : even though they are Iraqi citizens by record , they say Kurds are from Kurdistan - ' the land of the Kurds ' or from Mesopotamia - ' the land between the rivers ' .
#Text=Not Iraq , and recently the president of Kurdistan was claiming to announce the Kurdish State , which is a serious debate in the region .
#Text=Many Kurds also consider it unjust that there is no independent Kurdistan .

#Text=The Kurdish society consists of a variety of religions and beliefs ( such as Muslims , Christians , Jewish , Yazidis , Kakayis , Zoroastrians , Yarsanis , Hawaris , Ahli Haqs , etc. ) all of which normally coexist peacefully .
#Text=In general , Kurdish people are very friendly and hospitable , you can make friends with anybody and start talking to anyone on the street , so be open to new experiences .
#Text=Climate
#Text=Spring and fall are the best months to visit Iraqi Kurdistan , because temperatures are mild .
#Text=Winters can be cold , whereas summers are likely too hot for most outdoor activities .
#Text=The weather rarely gets extreme though , making Iraqi Kurdistan an attractive year round travel destination .
#Text=Orientation
#Text=Iraqi Kurdistan refers to the four northern Iraqi Provinces , which are autonomous of the central Iraqi government and ruled by the Kurdistan Regional Government ( KRG ) .
#Text=These provinces achieved de facto independence after an uprising in 1991 and their autonomy has now been enshrined into the Iraqi federal constitution .
#Text=The three Kurdish Provinces are Duhok , Erbil , and Sulaymaniya .
#Text=The KRG has applied for creating a fourth region around the city of Halabja .
#Text=Although the city Kirkuk is largely inhabited and controlled by Kurdish armed forces , the Peshmenga , it is still not under official administration of the KRG .
#Text=Kirkuk and parts of the Ninaveh and Diyala provinces are disputed .
#Text=The Kurds claim that these places are originally Kurdish , but were subjected to harsh Arabisation by the ousted Ba'ath Party .

#Text=The Kurds want these areas returned to Kurdish autonomy , something that has largely been realized during the ISIL rebellion in June 2014 after which the Kurdish armed forced took full control over the areas .
#Text=However , in October 2017 , Iraqi government forces pushed into these disputed areas and retook Kirkuk .
#Text=Cities
#Text=The major cities controlled by the Kurdish Regional Government ( KRG ) are
#Text=— the capital city of Kurdistan , its citadel Hawler is a UNESCO World Heritage site .
#Text=—
#Text=the town that was the scene for Saddam Hussein 's gruesome gas attack that killed 5000 people in 1988 now holds a number of memorials , monuments and cemeteries commemorating the event .
#Text=—
#Text=is the centre of education and culture in Iraqi Kurdistan .
#Text=The city features the best museums - the Amna Suraka and Slemani Museum , and a number of pleasant parks .

#Text=The only ski resort which is open in the region is accessible by a 4 km long Teleferic ( cable car ) from Bekhal .
#Text=Has a resort and activities park at 2,127 m above sea level .
#Text=—

#Text=Get in

#Text=Citizens of the EU , Australia , Brazil , Canada , Iceland , Japan , Kuwait , Lebanon , Monaco , New Zealand , Norway , Qatar , San Marino , South Korea , Switzerland , the UAE , and Vatican City are given a free stamp on arrival .
#Text=This is valid for 30 days after arrival , which can be extended by reporting to the Residency Office within 30 days of arrival .
#Text=This involves many forms to fill out , around $ 30 USD in fees as well as a compulsory blood test to check for hepatitis C and HIV .
#Text=Be prepared to wait for around 2 – 3 hours throughout this whole process .
#Text=Citizens of Iran and Turkey are given a free stamp with a validity of 15 days after arrival .
#Text=Most other nationalities must produce a valid " Iraq – Kurdistan Region " visa upon arrival .
#Text=Border control at land borders is fairly strict .
#Text=If you have a contact in Kurdistan , come armed with their name and address .
#Text=If you do n't , make sure you have a very good idea of what exactly you will be doing and where you will be staying .
#Text=You are also more likely to get in if travelling with someone else , and if you are well-dressed .
#Text=A visa for Iraqi Kurdistan can not be used to travel to other areas in Iraq , which includes Mosul as of 2019 .
#Text=When attempting to cross the Iraqi Kurdistan border , you will be sent back at the first military checkpoint encountered .
